comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The Portobello College building was built in 1807 and was originally a Hotel. archiseek.com/2010/1807-grand-canal-hotel-portobello-dubl... If we knew the story behind the baldacchino on the roof (missing from this photo) it might give a clue as to the date.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The baldacchino was an original feature as evidenced by this 1811 engraving www.flickr.com/photos/dublincitypubliclibraries/5736515136/ but must have been removed at some point and reinstated later.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I'm always open to correction (mainly by my wife) but I doubt that that is a traffic warden!  The traffic bye-laws were enforced by the Gardaí right up to the late 60's.  The gentleman in the uniform cap could be from any of a number of organisations or groups from the "Sally Anns", CIE, the Army or even a Garda?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] You're right! It's just the minute I spotted him, I thought Traffic Warden, probably because of the band on the hat...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] A tram inspector? We had bus inspectors - I bet there were tram inspectors.

His hat looks similar in shape to the tram driver's - could he be a conductor clocking off for the day?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Of course I'm right! I'm an expert on street nuisances and such like.  Glad you're still with us, that feather and the visit to A&E had us all worried!
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Quite possibly a tram inspector and they did have a braid band on the caps that would appear different to the rest of the cap in the right lighting conditions!  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Quite possible also, perhaps looking at the world going by in the canal below him or the crazy woman taking the photograph across the way;-)

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content:
Some history from Wiki

The hotel
The hotel at the harbour was opened in 1807 (the architect was James Colbourne).[8] In 1858 it was taken over by a Catholic order of nuns, who used it as an asylum (St. Mary's) for blind girls. A few years later they successfully appealed to the Guardians of the South Dublin Union for some finance (it cost £10 to keep a girl for a year), though the Irish Times in an editorial frowned upon this proselytising by "Romanists", while they lauded the efforts of the Protestant-run "Home for Orphans" at 7 South Richmond Street (which advertised frequently for "fresh souls to save" in the same newspaper).[10]

 
"The Portobello Hotel, and, facing it, the Grand Canal Tavern, 19th centuryTen years later the Asylum was sold to a Mr. Isaac Cole, who renovated it and returned it to its original function as a hotel, to accommodate 100 persons. It was popular among officers visiting the nearby Portobello Barracks (who would occasionally pop across South Richmond Street to the Grand Canal Tavern for a drink) and claimed it was the nearest hotel to the RDS grounds. However, it was slow in providing catering facilities - in 1871 a Rathmines businessman, in a letter to the Irish Times, lamented the absence of restaurants in the neighbourhood, and enjoined upon Mr. Cole to provide same, preferably a two-course meal for two shillings (the price to include beer and punch).[11] In the 20th century the building became a nursing home"

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Black & White Blended Scotch Whisky was first produced in 1884. www.whisky.com/brands/blackandwhite.html So between 1884 and 1948? I'd say closer to '48 just based on outfit of the gentleman on the bridge. The brand was trademarked in 1906, so that narrows it down quite a bit. Based on the labels I looked at online, seems to be with the script used in the 1930s. My best guess is 1930s or '40s. www.flickr.com/photos/ivanwalsh/2618494463/

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: If this photo is part of the Wiltshire collection it is the oldest photo in the collection by at least 3 years and a full five years early than the next Dublin photo. Can we be sure that the dates on Wikipedia are correct for the closure of tram lines - I can't find a source for the information on the No. 15 route.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Scurrying back to 1951[-1971] which are the usual dates for Wiltshire...

comment.author: 78620024@N07
comment._content: Wonderful photo.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From this CIE page: The last Dublin tram to run was the No.8 to Dalkey, south Co.Dublin on the 3rd July 1949 which marked the closure of the system. The tram was followed by a huge crowd all the way to Dalkey and into the tram shed, for the last time, in sadness. A downside to this crowd was many got on the tram and took seats and anything that could be taken as memorabilia of the Dublin trams. Another reference to that 1949 date.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I see a flying snail! So, after 1941.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You know what? You're right about July 1949, although one of our photos of that event incorrectly says 9 July 1949...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: More of it:The other key decision taken at that time was to close the tram network. This started in 1938 and had been mostly done by 1941 when wartime meant lack of availability of replacement buses, so the tram routes 6/7/8, 14 and 15 survived to the end of the decade.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The distinctive lamp on the twirly pole is gone in this 1959 shot (the pole is still twirling today, but the lamp has been changed again since 1959):

comment.author: 16693700@N03
comment._content: My guess is the chap in the hat is something to do with the canal/waterways

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] said above, the No. 15 was no more from the end of October 1948. Much outrage expressed in the pages of the Irish Independent during October. On Monday, 25 October it said in the Indo that:
"The Terenure route, on which Ireland's first city trams ran in 1872, will be served by buses from next Monday... The buses used will be Leyland double-deckers, 8 ft. wide (against the old 7' 6"), which allows greater comfort to passengers and to the conductor in the gangway. More powerful engines and synchromesh gears will give smoother movement and better speeds in between traffic jambs [sic]. About 50 tramcar bodies are to be sold, and can be inspected at Terenure Depot next week."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
